awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic geometry is the study of the qualitative properties of forms described by polynomial equations. The questions it addresses arise in many areas of science and mathematics, from statistical sampling to robotics and mathematical physics. This research project concerns the study of aspects of algebraic geometry related to syzygy theory, a sort of microscope that allows one to see details of polynomial equations that are not apparent from the equations themselves.

The investigator will work on problems in commutative algebra, algebraic geometry and computational methods for these fields. He will focus on four areas:  1) Cohen-Macaulay and Ulrich complexity of hypersurfaces: A central problem is to describe the minimal size of a non-free maximal Cohen-Macaulay module over a hypersurface, in particular over the permanent hypersurfaces.  2) The structure of high syzygies over complete intersections: Central problems are to give criteria for a module over a complete intersection to be a "high syzygy" in the sense of Eisenbud and Peeva; and to understand the relations between the even and odd parts of the infinite minimal free resolutions of modules over a complete intersection. 3) Duality for residual intersections: The central remaining open problem is to prove and extend a conjecture of van Straten and Warmt on the socle of a particular representation of the canonical module of a 0-dimensional residual intersection.  4) Tate resolutions for complexes of sheaves on a toric variety: The central problem is to define and compute a good analogue for toric varieties of the Tate resolution of a sheaf or a complex of sheaves on a projective space.

por.por_cntn:
A major theme of mathematics in the 19th and 20th and now 21st century has been the unification of number theory and geometry. Geometric objects such as curves and surfaces are now often treated by studying sets of functions defined on them; for example, the line of real numbers might be studied by considering the polynomial functions such as x^3+3x+1. Number theory, on the other hand, often treats numbers as if they were functions defined on a mythical geometric object whose points are the prime numbers; the "value" of a given number at a prime, in this view, is the remainder of the number after subtracting the highest multiple of that prime that is still smaller than the given number, so that for example the "value" of 8 at 3 is 8-2x3 = 2, and the "value" of 8 at 5 is 8-5 = 3.

The set of functions in all such cases forms a ring: a system of objects that can be multiplied, added and subtracted (but not, generally divided, since the value of a function at a point might be 0, and division by 0 is not allowed. The rings of functions like those above have another important property: multiplication is commutative, in the sense that f x g = g x f.

My project has been to study commutative rings of the sort that occur both in number theory and in geometry, through the interaction of the algebra and the geometry. Given a function defined on a surface, such as a polynomial

x^2+y^2-1

defined on the plane,

we expect that the function will take on the value 0 (colloquially, the function "vanishes") on a curve. For example, the function above takes the value 0 on the unit circle centered at the oriigin.

In general, sets of k functions on an n-dimensional space that are 0 simultaneously only in codimension k are called regular sequences, and the rings of functions defined on the common 0-locus are called complete intersections. My work over the last five years with collaborators Frank-Olaf Schreyer, Irena Peeva and Bernd Ulrich, has been related to different ways of studying these regular sequences and complete intersections, and the relationship of other sets of functions to them. 

During this period, I have also mentored a number of strong graduate students who now have positions in academia and industry; and I have participated in events that help students at many levels and universities learn the computational techniques involved in the subject.
